title: 114_hr1463
content: The "SEC Revolving Door Restriction Act of 2015" imposes a one-year employment restriction related to enforcement matters under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. This new section requires ethics opinions for individuals affected by the restriction. The "SEC Revolving Door Restriction Act of 2015" imposes a one-year employment restriction for former SEC employees working for entities involved in recent enforcement actions. Ethics opinions are required for individuals affected by this restriction. The "SEC Revolving Door Restriction Act of 2015" mandates ethics opinions for individuals involved in enforcement actions before working for related companies or individuals to ensure no appearance of impropriety. The "SEC Revolving Door Restriction Act of 2015" requires ethics opinions for individuals transitioning from enforcement actions to related companies to prevent conflicts of interest and maintain the integrity of ongoing cases. The Chairman of the Commission will establish regulations for issuing these opinions, and violators will face penalties under section 216 of title 18, United States Code. The "SEC Revolving Door Restriction Act of 2015" mandates ethics opinions for individuals transitioning from enforcement actions to prevent conflicts of interest. Violators may face penalties under section 216 of title 18, United States Code if they work for a company or individual within a year of leaving the Commission. Non-professional staff are exempt from this requirement. The "SEC Revolving Door Restriction Act of 2015" defines terms like "participated on" and "work for" in relation to enforcement actions to prevent conflicts of interest for individuals transitioning from the Commission. Penalties may apply under section 216 of title 18, United States Code for violations. The SEC Revolving Door Restriction Act of 2015 defines terms related to conflicts of interest for individuals transitioning from the Commission. A report analyzing the impact of the Act on employee recruitment and retention will be submitted to Congress one year after enactment. The amendment will take effect 60 days after enactment.
